title: John 3:5 — ‘born of water and Spirit’
summary: A key anchor text later traditions read in different ways: direct baptismal reference vs broader spiritual renewal.

title: Titus 3:5 — ‘washing of regeneration’
summary: Frequently cited as a direct link between salvation, washing, and renewal by the Holy Spirit.

title: Acts 2:38 — baptism ‘for the forgiveness of sins’
summary: Connects repentance, baptism, forgiveness; debates focus on how baptism relates to the forgiveness it proclaims.

title: 1 Peter 3:21 — ‘Baptism… now saves you’
summary: Strong salvation language paired with clarification that it is not mere external washing; later debates hinge on that clarification.

title: Justin Martyr, First Apology ch. 61 — regeneration language
summary: Justin describes baptism in conversion as connected with being ‘regenerated’ in a context of repentance and belief.

title: Justin Martyr, First Apology ch. 66 — ‘washing… remission… regeneration’
summary: Justin links baptismal washing to remission of sins and regeneration in the life of the Church.

title: Cyprian, Epistle to Fidus — infant baptism and forgiveness
summary: Cyprian’s counsel on infant baptism assumes baptism is closely connected with forgiveness/remission logic.

title: Augustine — baptism of infants and remission of sins
summary: Augustine argues baptism grants remission of sins even to infants, tying the issue to original sin and salvation debates.

title: Aquinas, ST III q.69 — effects of baptism (‘laver of regeneration’)
summary: Aquinas systematizes baptism’s effects, citing Titus 3:5 and connecting baptism to regeneration and remission of sins.

title: Luther, Small Catechism — baptism gives forgiveness and salvation
summary: Luther teaches baptism ‘works forgiveness of sins’ and gives salvation, grounded in God’s promise and received in faith.

title: Luther, Large Catechism — Word + water; not ‘mere water’
summary: Luther rejects reducing baptism to a bare external; its power is the Word joined to water, and he uses ‘laver of regeneration’ language.

title: Westminster Confession ch. 28 — efficacy not tied to the moment
summary: Westminster affirms real conferral of grace by the Spirit but denies a mechanical tie to the moment of administration.

title: Zwingli — baptism as covenant sign (summary)
summary: Zwingli emphasizes baptism as covenant sign/marker rather than traditional regenerating instrumentality.

title: Thirty-Nine Articles, Article 27 — ‘sign of regeneration… as by an instrument’
summary: Anglican formularies describe baptism as more than a badge: a sign of regeneration/new birth ‘as by an instrument’ when rightly received.

title: Catechism of the Catholic Church — baptism as regeneration through water and the word
summary: The Catechism summarizes baptism as regeneration/new birth and liberation from sin, with incorporation into Christ and the Church.
